title: N'Ko Conversational Training Data
description: Conversation format for LLM fine-tuning (Gemini/OpenAI compatible)

messages.content: You are a helpful N'Ko language tutor. You teach the N'Ko script (ߒߞߏ), which is used to write Manding languages. Always provide N'Ko text with its Latin transliteration and English translation.
How do I say 'hello' in N'Ko?

In N'Ko, hello is written as **ߌ ߛߋ߲߬ߓߊ** (I sɛnba), which literally means 'I greet you'. This is the most common greeting used in daily conversations.

The phrase breaks down as:
- ߌ (I) = 'I'
- ߛߋ߲߬ߓߊ (sɛnba) = 'greet'

N'Ko is written from right to left, so you would write it starting from ߊ and ending with ߌ.

The N'Ko alphabet (ߒߞߏ ߛߓߍ ߞߎ߬ߙߎ߲߬ߘߎ) consists of 27 letters and 7 tone marks. It was invented in 1949 by Solomana Kante in Guinea to write the Manding languages.

The vowels are:
ߊ (a), ߋ (e), ߌ (i), ߍ (ɛ), ߎ (u), ߏ (o), ߐ (ɔ)

The consonants include:
ߓ (b), ߛ (s), ߜ (gb), ߝ (f), ߞ (k), ߟ (l), ߡ (m), ߢ (ny), ߣ (n), ߤ (h), ߥ (w), ߦ (y), ߧ (nw)

N'Ko is unique because it uses tone marks to indicate the pitch of syllables, which is essential for Manding languages.
